title: How accurate is Reza Aslan's book 'Zealot'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Reza is a top scholar in the field of religion. He knows his stuff and cannot be dismissed lightly. But people should know that Reza’s view of the historical Jesus is only one view among several other theories. There are two prominent models: Reza’s Jesus is that of an end-times preacher (aka, apocalyptic and eschatological) who is zealous for the Temple and for Judaism’s independence from Rome. This is actually an older model of the historical Jesus first made popular by Dr.Albert Schweitzer (yes, that Dr. Schweitzer). Reza’s “Zealot Jesus” was actually more popular a hundred years ago than it is today.The more popular scholarly view of the historical Jesus is currently that of “Jesus the wisdom teacher”. This Jesus may have started out in the “endtimes” tradition from John Baptist’s influence, but instead of warning that the Kingdom of God was coming soon, he preached that the Kingdom had already arrived and was being fulfilled by him and his followers. This view was presented in the 1980’s by Robert Funk, John Dominic Crossan, Markus Borg and other scholars of the “Jesus Seminar”.There have been other models of the “historical Jesus”: Jesus the guerilla revolutionary, Jesus the powerful exorcist, Jesus the charismatic healer, Jesus the prophet of social change, Jesus the Reconstructionist Jew, Jesus the Messianic King, Jesus the Essene, etc. Most of these have come and gone without much proof. The two theories that have solid historical research behind them are the two I’ve enumerated. Reza is trying to bring the older theory back into vogue again. He will make headway with the public, but what Reza has written will likely not sway any of the scholars in the field.
